title: Qaa
text:
Qaa (<a href="Arabic">Arabic</a>: القاع), El Qaa, Al Qaa or Masharih al-Qaa is a town in <a href="Baalbek-Hermel%20Governorate">Baalbek-Hermel Governorate</a>, <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>.
It has a mainly <a href="Melkite%20Greek%20Catholic%20Church">Greek Catholic</a> population.
The village has been the target of attacks from Syrian government and anti-government forces.
History.
In 1838, <a href="Eli%20Smith">Eli Smith</a> noted Qaa's population as being predominantly <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic Christian</a>.
The <a href="Syrian%20army">Syrian army</a> invaded <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a> at 4 a.m. on 1 September 2012 and kidnapped a farmer from the town as part of escalating incursions during the <a href="Syrian%20civil%20war">Syrian civil war</a>. The invasion lasted for forty minutes before the unit withdrew. A house in Qaa had previously been hit by a <a href="shell%20%28projectile%29">shell</a> fired by the Syrian army.
On the 27 June 2016, at least five people in Qaa were killed and thirteen others wounded in an attack by four <a href="suicide%20bomber">suicide bomber</a>s.
Archaeology.
Along with <a href="Maqne%20I">Maqne I</a>, Qaa is a type site of the <a href="Shepherd%20Neolithic">Shepherd Neolithic</a> <a href="industry%20%28archaeology%29">industry</a>. The site is located north west of the town, north of a path leading from Qaa to <a href="Hermel">Hermel</a>. It was discovered by M. Billaux and the materials recovered were documented by <a href="Henri%20Fleisch">Henri Fleisch</a> in 1966. The area was lightly cultivated with a thin soil covering the <a href="Conglomerate%20%28geology%29">conglomerates</a>. The flints were divided into three groups of a reddish brown, light brown and one that was mostly chocolate and grey colored with a radiant "desert shine".
The Shepherd Neolithic industry can be defined firstly by being small and thick in size, with <a href="Lithic%20flake">flake</a>s commonly ranging from to , the thickness distinguishing them from <a href="geometric">geometric</a> <a href="microlith">microlith</a>s. Their second characteristic is the limited number of forms that the tools take, apart from cores being transverse <a href="racloir">racloir</a>s on small flakes, strong-pointed borers, denticulated or notched thick, short blades and end-scrapers. It was thirdly characterized by a lack of known <a href="typology%20%28archaeology%29">typology</a>, with only occasional use of <a href="Levallois%20technique">Levallois technique</a>. It was determined to be definitely later than the <a href="Mesolithic">Mesolithic</a> but without any usual forms from the <a href="Upper%20Paleolithic">Upper Paleolithic</a> or <a href="pottery">pottery</a> <a href="Neolithic">Neolithic</a>. Henri Fleisch tentatively suggested the industry to be <a href="Epipaleolithic">Epipaleolithic</a> and suggested it may have been used by <a href="Nomadic%20pastoralism">nomadic shepherds</a>. The Shepherd Neolithic has largely been ignored and understudied following the outbreak of the <a href="Lebanese%20civil%20war">Lebanese civil war</a>.
